title: Chest Pain
description: Chest pain is any discomfort or pain felt in the chest area. It may feel sharp, dull, heavy, burning, or tight — and may spread to the arms, neck, jaw, or back. It can be caused by heart problems, but also lung, muscle, stomach, or anxiety-related issues.

sections.heading: Common Symptoms
sections.content:
Tightness or pressure in chest

Sharp or stabbing pain

Burning sensation (may feel like heartburn)

Pain that spreads to jaw, arms, shoulder, or back

Shortness of breath

Sweating, nausea, or dizziness

Rapid heartbeat

Pain when breathing deeply or coughing

sections.heading: Possible Causes of Chest Pain
sections.content:
1) Heart-Related (More Serious)
- Heart attack (Myocardial infarction)
- Angina (reduced blood flow to the heart)
- Pericarditis (inflammation of heart lining)
- Aortic dissection (tear in the main artery – life-threatening)

2) Lung-Related
- Pulmonary embolism (blood clot in lungs)
- Pneumonia or pleurisy
- Collapsed lung (pneumothorax)

3) Digestive-Related
- Acid reflux (GERD)
- Heartburn
- Gallbladder issues

4) Muscle or Bone
- Muscle strain
- Rib injury or inflammation (costochondritis)

5) Anxiety or Panic Attacks
- Chest tightness, fast breathing, rapid heartbeat
- Often mistaken for a heart problem

sections.heading: Precautions
sections.content:
Know your risk factors: smoking, high BP, diabetes, stress, obesity, family history

Avoid heavy meals, smoking, and excess alcohol

Manage stress and anxiety

Exercise regularly under medical guidance

sections.heading: When Chest Pain Is an Emergency – Go to ER If:
sections.content:
Sudden, intense pressure or squeezing in chest

Pain radiates to arm, jaw, back, or shoulder

Shortness of breath, sweating, nausea

Fainting or dizziness

Irregular or rapid heartbeat

Pain lasts more than 5 minutes and doesn’t go away with rest

History of heart disease

This may be a heart attack — call emergency services (eg, 112 or 108 in India) immediately.

sections.heading: What to Do (First Aid)
sections.content:
If You Suspect a Heart Attack:
- Have the person sit down and stay calm
- Loosen tight clothing
- Call emergency services immediately
- If advised and available, give aspirin (unless allergic)
- Do CPR if the person collapses and stops breathing

If Not a Heart Attack:
- Rest and avoid activity
- Try antacids (if suspecting heartburn)
- Track symptoms and see a doctor

sections.heading: Medicines (Only by Doctor’s Advice)
sections.content:
Aspirin or nitroglycerin – for heart-related issues

Antacids or PPIs – for acid reflux

Painkillers – for muscle/rib pain

Anti-anxiety medicines – for panic-related pain

Blood thinners or oxygen – in emergency cases

sections.heading: What Not to Do
sections.content:
Don’t ignore chest pain, even if it goes away

Don’t drive yourself to the hospital if symptoms are serious

Don’t take heart medicines without doctor’s advice

Don’t assume it’s 'just gas' — get checked
